segment.source: This topic for IT professionals shows how to create an AppLocker rule for packaged apps with a publisher condition.
segment.target: This topic for IT professionals shows how to create an AppLocker rule for packaged apps with a publisher condition.

segment.source: Packaged apps, also known as Universal Windows apps, are based on an app model that ensures that all the files within an app package share the same identity.
segment.target: Packaged apps, also known as Universal Windows apps, are based on an app model that ensures that all the files within an app package share the same identity.

segment.source: Therefore, it is possible to control the entire app using a single AppLocker rule as opposed to the non-packaged apps where each file within the app could have a unique identity.
segment.target: Therefore, it is possible to control the entire app using a single AppLocker rule as opposed to the non-packaged apps where each file within the app could have a unique identity.

segment.source: Windows does not support unsigned packaged apps which implies all packaged apps must be signed.
segment.target: Windows does not support unsigned packaged apps which implies all packaged apps must be signed.

segment.source: AppLocker supports only publisher rules for packaged apps.
segment.target: AppLocker supports only publisher rules for packaged apps.

segment.source: A publisher rule for a packaged app is based on the following information:
segment.target: A publisher rule for a packaged app is based on the following information:

segment.source: Publisher of the package
segment.target: Publisher of the package

segment.source: Package name
segment.target: Package name

segment.source: Package version
segment.target: Package version

segment.source: All the files within a package as well as the package installer share these attributes.
segment.target: All the files within a package as well as the package installer share these attributes.

segment.source: Therefore, an AppLocker rule for a packaged app controls both the installation as well as the running of the app.
segment.target: Therefore, an AppLocker rule for a packaged app controls both the installation as well as the running of the app.

segment.source: Otherwise, the publisher rules for packaged apps are no different than the rest of the rule collections; they support exceptions, can be increased or decreased in scope, and can be assigned to users and groups.
segment.target: Otherwise, the publisher rules for packaged apps are no different than the rest of the rule collections; they support exceptions, can be increased or decreased in scope, and can be assigned to users and groups.

segment.source: For info about the publisher condition, see Understanding the publisher rule condition in AppLocker.
segment.target: For info about the publisher condition, see Understanding the publisher rule condition in AppLocker.

segment.source: You can perform this task by using the Group Policy Management Console for an AppLocker policy in a Group Policy Object (GPO) or by using the Local Security Policy snap-in for an AppLocker policy on a local computer or in a security template.
segment.target: You can perform this task by using the Group Policy Management Console for an AppLocker policy in a Group Policy Object (GPO) or by using the Local Security Policy snap-in for an AppLocker policy on a local computer or in a security template.

segment.source: To create a packaged app rule
segment.target: To create a packaged app rule

segment.source: Open the AppLocker console.
segment.target: Open the AppLocker console.

segment.source: On the Action menu, or by right-clicking on Packaged app Rules, click Create New Rule.
segment.target: On the Action menu, or by right-clicking on Packaged app Rules, click Create New Rule.

segment.source: On the Before You Begin page, click Next.
segment.target: On the Before You Begin page, click Next.

segment.source: On the Permissions page, select the action (allow or deny) and the user or group that the rule should apply to, and then click Next.
segment.target: On the Permissions page, select the action (allow or deny) and the user or group that the rule should apply to, and then click Next.

segment.source: On the Publisher page, you can select a specific reference for the packaged app rule and set the scope for the rule.
segment.target: On the Publisher page, you can select a specific reference for the packaged app rule and set the scope for the rule.

segment.source: The following table describes the reference options.
segment.target: The following table describes the reference options.

segment.source: Use an installed packaged app as a reference
segment.target: Use an installed packaged app as a reference

segment.source: If selected, AppLocker requires you to choose an app that is already installed on which to base your new rule.
segment.target: If selected, AppLocker requires you to choose an app that is already installed on which to base your new rule.

segment.source: AppLocker uses the publisher, package name and package version to define the rule.
segment.target: AppLocker uses the publisher, package name and package version to define the rule.

segment.source: You want the Sales group only to use the app named Microsoft.BingMaps for its outside sales calls.
segment.target: You want the Sales group only to use the app named Microsoft.BingMaps for its outside sales calls.

segment.source: The Microsoft.BingMaps app is already installed on the device where you are creating the rule, so you choose this option, and select the app from the list of apps installed on the computer and create the rule using this app as a reference.
segment.target: The Microsoft.BingMaps app is already installed on the device where you are creating the rule, so you choose this option, and select the app from the list of apps installed on the computer and create the rule using this app as a reference.

segment.source: Use a packaged app installer as a reference
segment.target: Use a packaged app installer as a reference

segment.source: If selected, AppLocker requires you to choose an app installer on which to base your new rule.
segment.target: If selected, AppLocker requires you to choose an app installer on which to base your new rule.

segment.source: A packaged app installer has the .appx extension.
segment.target: A packaged app installer has the .appx extension.

segment.source: AppLocker uses the publisher, package name and package version of the installer to define the rule.
segment.target: AppLocker uses the publisher, package name and package version of the installer to define the rule.

segment.source: Your company has developed a number of internal line-of-business packaged apps.
segment.target: Your company has developed a number of internal line-of-business packaged apps.

segment.source: The app installers are stored on a common file share.
segment.target: The app installers are stored on a common file share.

segment.source: Employees can install the required apps from that file share.
segment.target: Employees can install the required apps from that file share.

segment.source: You want to allow all your employees to install the Payroll app from this share.
segment.target: You want to allow all your employees to install the Payroll app from this share.

segment.source: So you choose this option from the wizard, browse to the file share and choose the installer for the Payroll app as a reference to create your rule.
segment.target: So you choose this option from the wizard, browse to the file share and choose the installer for the Payroll app as a reference to create your rule.

segment.source: Applies to Any publisher
segment.target: Applies to Any publisher

segment.source: This is the least restrictive scope condition for an Allow rule.
segment.target: This is the least restrictive scope condition for an Allow rule.

segment.source: It permits every packaged app to run or install.
segment.target: It permits every packaged app to run or install.

segment.source: Conversely, if this is a Deny rule, then this option is the most restrictive because it denies all apps from installing or running.
segment.target: Conversely, if this is a Deny rule, then this option is the most restrictive because it denies all apps from installing or running.

segment.target: You want the Sales group to use any packaged app from any signed publisher.

segment.target: You set the permissions to allow the Sales group to be able to run any app.

segment.target: This scopes the rule to all apps published by a particular publisher.
